document.masterDocTitle: The spider wasp genus Telostholus Haupt, 1929 (Hymenoptera, Pompilidae) in Malaysia, with the description of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The spider wasp genus Telostholus Haupt, 1929 (Hymenoptera, Pompilidae) in Malaysia, with the description of four new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined .
Holotype
, ♀ , Malaysia , Pahang ,
30 km NE Raub
, Lata Lembik ,
300 m
, 3°56’ N 101°38’ E , IV–V .2002 ( E. Jendek , O. Šauša ) [OLL].

Diagnosis . Female . The female of this new species can be separated from those of other congeners by the following combination of characters: (1) eye broad ( Fig. 15 ), half of MID 1.0 times eye width; (2) POD: OOD = 2.2; (3) clypeus with slightly depressed and translucent anterior rim ( Fig. 12 ); (4) propodeum with tubercle posterolaterally ( Figs 18–20 ); (5) fore wing ( Fig. 21 ) with distinct light translucent area along apical margin, broad brown subapical band, and entirely brown cells 1A , M+Cu , and Cub ; (6) F1 as long as scape. Male . Unknown.

Legs . Proleg without spines, except following: protibia outer face with two spines, protibia with few differentlength stout spines apically, protarsomere 1 with three longitudinal rows of very short spines ventrally, protarsomeres 2 and 3 with median longitudinal row of very short spines ventrally, protarsomere 4 with long spines apically. Protarsomere 1 length 1.5 times protarsomere 2–4 length combined. Mesofemur with two short spine dorso-apically. Metafemur with 4–5 short spines dorso-apically. Meso- and metatibia with scattered long spines. Metatibia longer spur length 0.65 times metatarsomere 1 length. Meso- and metatarsomere 1 with spines which shorter and rare than on tibia; meso- and metatarsomeres 2–4 ventrally with median longitudinal row of short spines; meso- and metatarsomere 2 except median row of spines with two spines on both sides of row. All tarsomeres 5 without spines ventrally. Tarsal claws symmetrical and bifid, inner tooth broad and obliquely truncated.

Wings . Fore wing ( Fig. 21 ) with distinct light translucent area along apical margin, broad brown band subapically, brown marking at base of M , pterostigma and cells ( 1A , M+Cu , Cub and C ) almost entirely brown. Pterostigma length 4.5 times its height (on inner distance) and 1.4 times Rs
2
. Second submarginal cell length 2.9 times its maximum height, narrowed on vein Rs by 0.51 times its own length on vein M , receiving crossvein 1m-cu at basal 0.33 and receiving crossvein 2m-cu at basal 0.9; crossvein 3rs-m arched towards wing apex; crossvein cu-a straight, originating at separation of vein M+CuA ; vein M ending far from wing margin; vein Cu
1
not touching wing margin. Hind wing ( Fig. 22 ) translucent, with slightly brownish apical portion; crossvein cu-a evenly arched and anterofurcal.
Metasoma in dorsal view conical shaped, as wide as mesosoma ( Fig. 14 ). Posterior margin of T1–T5 and S1–S5 slightly emarginate medially.

Sculpture . Body matt, except mandible and labrum polished. Body with inconspicuous microsculpture. Frons micropunctate, with well impressed basomedian line. Metapostnotum matt, with fine transverse striae. Dorsum of propodeum densely and minutely punctate. Antenna and legs matt.
Etymology . The specific name refers to a peculiar character of the clypeus, i.e. its anterior rim depressed and translucent. Treated as an adjective in apposition.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 12–22 .
Telostholus clypeatus
sp. nov .
, ♀, holotype. 12, clypeus and labrum in frontal view. 13 and 14, habitus (13, in lateral view; 14, in dorsal view). 15, head in frontal view. 16, head and pronotum in lateral view. 17, head and pronotum in dorsal view. 18, mesosoma part. in dorsal view. 19, propodeum in dorso-lateral view. 20, propodeum in lateral view. 21, fore wing. 22, hind wing. Scale bar: 1.0 mm for 13, 14; 0.5 mm for 18, 21, 22; 0.2 mm for 12, 15–17, 19, 20.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks . The female of this new species is similar to those of
Telostholus orientalis
,
T. yasumatsui
,
T. malayensis
sp. nov .
, and
T. tomentosus
sp. nov .
, but can be separated from them by having the following characteristics: eye broad ( Fig. 15 ), half of MID 1.0 times eye width (eye narrower, 1.4–1,7 in
T. orientalis
and
T. yasumatsui
); POD: OOD = 2.2 ( 1.4–1.7 in
T. orientalis
and
T. yasumatsui
); cells 1A , M+Cu , and Cub completely brown (par- tially brown in
T. yasumatsui
); dorsum of propodeum evenly merging with its posterior face not forming distinct edge (forming distinct edge in
T. orientalis
); clypeus ( Fig. 12 ) with slightly depressed and translucent anterior rim (without depressed and translucent anterior rim in
T. malayensis
sp. nov .
and
T. tomentosus
sp. nov .
( Figs 23 , 34 )); dorsum of propodeum ( Fig. 20 ) in lateral view slightly convex (strongly convex in
T. malayensis
sp. nov .
and
T. tomentosus
sp. nov .
( Figs 31 , 42 )).
